text.p: NARODNA OBRODA - Slovakia on Monday begins the second round of its case in the International Court of Justice in a law suit against Hungary over the controversial Gabcikovo dam on the Danube River.

- Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar said return of the Slovak part of former Czechoslovak gold reserves, currently held in Prague, still remained one of unsolved aspects of the split of the federation in 1993.

- Slovakia and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) have agreed on the sale of the bank's 10.5 percent stake in refinery Slovnaft to the privatisation agency, the National Property Fund.
- Engineering company Povazske Strojarne won a contract to supply engines to Russian-made jet fighters JAK 130 which will be used by the Russian army.
- Romania has become the sixth member of the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA).
- French car producer Peugeot said it planned to increase its sales in Slovakia to 2,000 units in 1997, from last year's 1,296.

HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - Slovak industry employed around 619,000 people in January this year, down 12 percent against the same month in last year. The number of employees in construction sector eased by 4.2 percent year-on-year, while transport sector recorded a decrease of 4.6 percent.
- Steel maker VSZ Kosice has submitted its bid in a privatisation tender for Hungarian steel company OAM Kft Ozd.

- State-owned Slovak Railways (ZRS) estimates its financial damages from a recent strike of Czech railway workers at some 126 million crowns, but said the final sum will be higher as it would also include sanctions for failing to manage transports from Russia and Ukraine.

SME - President Michal Kovac has said Prosecutor General Michal Valo was responsible that several serious criminal outbreaks over the past few weeks still remained unsolved. Kovac warned that the power of mafia gangs is spreading over the country and accused these gangs of being linked to the privatisation process.
- Slovak Railways said it expected to post a 1996 loss of around 497 million crowns, compared with the originally planned profit of about one billion crowns.

- The Foreign Ministry said recalling its ambassador in Prague for consultations last week was nothing unusual and that the "short-term consultations should help find solution for some problems in the Czech-Slovak relations".
